title: About Me
text:
My passion for wildlife runs deep. I’ve always been fascinated by the ways animals interact with their environment, and that curiosity has guided my academic focus. At UCSB, I’ve explored these interests through coursework, research, and field experiences. One of my favorite campus involvements is with The Wildlife Society, which has connected me with others who share my love for wildlife and conservation.



Harris Hawk seen through binoculars





Harris Hawk seen on field guide

title: About Me
text:
Campus and Community Involvement
Beyond academics, I’ve been deeply engaged in the UCSB and Santa Barbara communities. As an officer for The Wildlife Society at UCSB, I’ve helped organize events with professional wildlife biologists, led club meetings, and built a space for students to explore conservation careers. I’m also a Bren Environmental Studies Fellow, participating in a cohort committed to increasing diversity and inclusion in the environmental field.
In addition, I work as a worm wrangler with UCSB’s Associated Students Department of Public Worms, where I manage food waste and compost production. It’s been incredibly rewarding to contribute to a closed-loop food system that benefits the campus garden and student food programs.



Worms in compost from the Department of Public Worms


Our finished compost supports the growth of produce like these vibrant tomatoes at UCSB’s Edible Campus Student Farm:



Tomatoes grown with DPW compost at the UCSB Student Farm

title: About Me
text:
Family and Friends
Outside of school and work, I deeply value time with the people—and pets—I love. I’m especially close with my family in Northern Virginia and always look forward to hikes, camping trips, and board games when I’m home. Being far from our family dog, Marlo, can be tough, but the enthusiastic greeting he gives me whenever I return reminds me that I’ve never been forgotten. I’ve also built lasting friendships through UCSB, study abroad programs, and campus organizations—relationships that have been a meaningful and memorable part of my journey.



Marlo on a hike





Graduation photo with friends

title: Projects
text: Welcome to my Projects page! Here you’ll find examples of my research and data work, including my senior thesis and exploratory analyses using code.

title: Projects
text:
Senior Thesis: Raccoons and Refuse
Title: Raccoons and Refuse: Evaluating Food Waste Management Practices at UCSB and Their Implications for Raccoon Behavior, Ecology, and Health
This research project investigates how different waste management practices on the UC Santa Barbara campus influence raccoon foraging behavior. Using camera traps, I tracked raccoon interactions with open, half-open, and closed trash bins over 18 nights. I analyzed interaction frequency across trash types and discussed implications for raccoon learned foraging, health, overall ecology and human-wildlife coexistence on campus. My work also provides recommendations for more sustainable waste management on UCSB’s campus.
Click here to read my full senior thesis (PDF)



Raccoons seen on camera trap foraging at open trash can site



Mapping Raccoon-Waste Interactions
The interactive map below displays the three trash can monitoring sites from my senior thesis research at UC Santa Barbara. Each site—categorized as “Open,” “Semi-Open,” or “Closed” based on its accessibility to wildlife—is marked by a circle scaled to reflect the number of raccoon interactions captured by camera traps. The map helps visualize how raccoon activity varied spatially in response to differences in trash can design, with far more interactions occurring at the open site.

library(leaflet)

# Data
trash_sites <- data.frame(
  Site = c("Open Can", "Semi–Open Can", "Closed Can"),
  Latitude = c(34.41553, 34.412422, 34.412200),
  Longitude = c(-119.84517, -119.843723, -119.848092),
  Interactions = c(31, 3, 1)
)

# Map
trash_sites$Color <- c("red", "orange", "blue")  # open, semi-open, closed
leaflet(trash_sites) %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  addCircleMarkers(
    ~Longitude, ~Latitude,
    radius = 10,
    color = ~Color,
    fillOpacity = 0.7,
    label = ~paste(Site, "<br>", Interactions, "interactions")
  )

title: Projects
section: Example Code Project: Chi-Square Test and Visualization
text:
Example Code Project: Chi-Square Test and Visualization
In this example, I use R to create a barplot and run a chi-square test on raccoon visit frequencies to different bin types and visualize the results. This simple analysis helped me determine whether raccoons showed a preference among the different trash can designs, data that was useful to me when talking about how waste management influences raccoon behavior.

Code

# Data
raccoon_data <- data.frame( TrashCanType = c("Open", "Semi-Open", "Closed"), Interactions = c(31, 3, 1) )

#Load Package
library(ggplot2)

#Barplot
ggplot(raccoon_data, 
       aes(
         x = TrashCanType, 
         y = Interactions, 
         fill = TrashCanType)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  labs( 
    title = "Raccoon Interactions by Trash Can Type", 
    x = "Trash Can Type", 
    y = "Number of Interactions" ) + 
  theme_minimal()







# Chi-Square Test
chisq_test <- chisq.test(raccoon_data$Interactions)


Results
This barplot shows the difference in interactions by trash can type. The open site had 31 interactions, the semi-open had three and the closed has just one.
The test compared this observed distribution of raccoon interactions to the expected distribution if raccoons had interacted equally with all three trash can types. Under this null hypothesis, each can type would be expected to have approximately 11.67 interactions (35 total interactions divided evenly across three categories).
The chi-square analysis yielded a test statistic of χ²(2, N = 35) = 48.22, with a p-value < 0.0001. This result indicates a highly significant difference between observed and expected values, providing strong evidence that raccoon interactions at each site are not evenly distributed, and that trash can design plays a role in raccoon interaction with food waste.

title: Outside the Classroom
text: In my free time, I enjoy spending time in nature and exploring new places. Here’s a little about my hobbies and interests.

title: Home
text:
Fiona Jeweler






Welcome!
Thanks for visiting my website! I’m Fiona Jeweler, and I created this site to share a bit about myself, including my academic journey, research projects, and interests beyond the classroom.
I’m originally from Northern Virginia and am currently completing my Bachelor of Science in Environmental Studies at UC Santa Barbara. I’m passionate about wildlife conservation, sustainable resource management, and understanding human-wildlife interactions.
Right now, I’m working on a senior thesis that investigates how food waste management at UCSB influences raccoon foraging behavior. You can more about that and other projects I’ve worked on by visiting the Projects page.
This site also includes a Courses page outlining what I’ve studied at UCSB and while abroad in Chile and Australia, an Outside the Classroom page featuring my favorite outdoor and travel interests, an About Me section with more detail on my background and experiences, and a Résumé/CV for a quick overview of my academic and professional journey.
Feel free to explore—and don’t hesitate to contact me!


Education
B.S. Environmental Studies, with Honors (2025)
University of California, Santa Barbara
